clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Portion Size of Multiple Items at a Meal on Food Intake of Adults

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK)

brief_summary.textblock: This study tests the effect of serving larger portions of all foods in a meal on the outcome of food and energy intake. Using a crossover design, participants are served the meal once a week for four weeks and the portion sizes are varied at each meal. Some of the foods served at the meal are low in calorie density (calories per gram) and some are higher in calorie density. The aim is to determine whether intake in response to larger portions differs depending on characteristics of the subjects or of the foods.

primary_outcome.description: Differences in weight of food consumed (grams) at the meals
Differences in energy of food consumed (kilocalories) at the meals
Differences in energy density of food consumed (kilocalories per gram) at the meal

secondary_outcome.description: Differences in ratings of hunger and satiety either before or after the meal, as assessed by 100-mm visual analog scales (mm)

secondary_outcome.measure: Differences in ratings of food properties
secondary_outcome.description: Differences in ratings of food properties (such as taste or healthfulness) as assessed either by 100-mm visual analog scales (mm) or ranking (rank order)

arm_group.description: Food portion size Test meal consists of baseline (100%) portion size of all foods
Food portion size Test meal consists of portion sizes of all foods that are 133% the size of baseline portions
Food portion size Test meal consists of portion sizes of all foods that are 167% the size of baseline portions
Food portion size Test meal consists of portion sizes of all foods that are 200% the size of baseline portions

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Body mass index of 18 to 40 kg/square meter
- Regularly eat three meals per day
- Willing to eat foods served at test meals
Exclusion Criteria:
- Food allergies or restrictions
- Dieting to gain or lose weight
- Taking medications known to affect appetite
- Smoker
- Athlete in training
- Currently pregnant or breast-feeding
- Questionnaire score indicative of depression
- Questionnaire score indicative of disordered eating attitudes
